author: Matthew Hughes
title: Congress just passed a law that tightens America’s email privacy laws
text:
51 shares 
In a welcome tightening of the privacy laws surrounding email communications, Congress has passed the Email Privacy Act (H.R. 387) . This law, which has bipartisan support, and was introduced by Colorado Rep. Jared Polis and Kansas Rep. Kevin requires the government to obtain a warrant before accessing the email of American citizens. 
The previous law that covered email privacy left a lot to be desired. The Electronic Communications Privacy Act (ECPA), which was passed in 1986, lets the government obtain email records without a warrant, provided the emails themselves are more than 180 days old and are stored on third-party servers.
